Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: The time -- 7:15 A.M., WOR, New York. The temperature, outside, 84 -- Friends -- is your life worth one dollar?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Indo-China -- Jeff predicted it would go sky-high.

Speaker: bryce
Dialogue: From the looks of Davidson's cable, it might even go higher than that. And we haven't even got a camera over there.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: This could go off in a month -- or an hour.

Speaker: bryce
Dialogue: I'll pull somebody out of Japan.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Get me L. B. Jefferies.

Speaker: bryce
Dialogue: Jefferies?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Name me a better photographer.

Speaker: bryce
Dialogue: But his leg!

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Don't worry -- it comes off today.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: I mean the cast.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Jefferies.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Congratulations, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: For getting rid of that cast.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Who said I was getting rid of it?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: This is Wednesday.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Gunnison -- how did you get to be such a big editor -- with such a small memory?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Wrong day?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Wrong week. Next Wednesday I emerge from this plaster cocoon.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: That's too bad, Jeff. Well, I guess I can't be lucky every day. Forget I called.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah. I sure feel sorry for you, Gunnison. Must be rough on you thinking of me wearing this cast another whole week.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: That one week is going to cost me my best photographer -- and you a big assignment.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: There's no point in even talking about it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Indo-China. Got a code tip from the bureau chief this morning. The place is about to go up in smoke.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Didn't I tell you! Didn't I tell you it was the next place to watch?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Okay. When do I leave? Half-hour? An hour?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: With that cast on -- you don't.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stop sounding stuffy. I'll take pictures from a jeep. From a water buffalo if necessary.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: You're too valuable to the magazine for us to play around with. I'll send Morgan or Lambert.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Swell. I get myself half-killed for you -- and you reward me by stealing my assignments.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: I didn't ask you to stand in the middle of that automobile race track.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You asked for something dramatically different! You got it!

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: So did you. Goodbye, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You've got to get me out of here! Six weeks -- sitting in a two-room apartment with nothing to do but look out the window at the neighbors!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's worse than the Chinese water torture.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Read some good books.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I've been taking pictures so long I don't know how to read anymore.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: I'll send you some comic books.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Listen -- if you don't pull me out of this swamp of boredom -- I'll do something drastic.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll -- I'll get married. Then I'll never be able to go anywhere.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: It's about time you got married -- before you turn into a lonesome and bitter old man.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Can you see me -- rushing home to a hot apartment every night to listen to the automatic laundry, the electric dishwasher, the garbage disposal and a nagging wife.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Jeff -- wives don't nag anymore -- they discuss.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah? Maybe in the high rent districts they discuss -- but in my neighborhood, they still nag.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Well -- you know best. Call you later, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Next time, have some good news.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: The New York State sentence for a peeping Tom is six months in the workhouse!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hello Stella.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: And there aren't any windows in the workhouse.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Years ago, they used to put out your eyes with a hot poker. Is one of those bikini bombshells you always watch worth a hot poker?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: We've grown to be a race of peeping Toms. What people should do is stand outside their own houses and look in once in a while.  What do you think of that for homespun philosophy?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Well, I only quote from the best.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now look, Stella --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: See it you can break a hundred.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I shoulda been a Gypsy fortune teller, instead of an insurance company nurse. I got a nose for trouble -- can smell it ten miles away.  You heard of the stock market crash in '29?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I predicted it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Simple. I was nursing a director of General Motors. Kidney ailment they said. Nerves, I said. Then I asked myself -- what's General Motors got to be nervous about?  Overproduction. Collapse, I answered. When General Motors has to go to the bathroom ten times a day -- the whole country's ready to let go.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella -- in economics, a kidney ailment has no relationship to the stock market. Absolutely none.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: It crashed, didn't it?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I can smell trouble right in this apartment. You broke your leg. You look out the window. You see things you shouldn't. Trouble. I can see you now, in front of the judge, flanked by lawyers in blue double- breasted suits. You're pleading, "Judge, it was only innocent fun. I love my neighbors like a father." -- The Judge answers, "Congratulations. You just gave birth to three years in Dannemora."

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Right now I'd even welcome trouble.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You've got a hormone deficiency.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How can you tell that from a thermometer!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Those sultry sun-worshipers you watch haven't raised your temperature one degree in four weeks.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I think you're right. There is going to be some trouble around here.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I knew it!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Don't you ever heat that stuff up.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Gives your circulation something to fight.  What kind of trouble?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa Fremont.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You must be kidding. A beautiful young woman, and you a reasonably healthy specimen of manhood.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She expects me to marry her.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: That's normal.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I don't want to.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: That's abnormal.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm not ready for marriage.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Nonsense. A man is always ready for marriage -- with the right girl. And Lisa Fremont is the right girl for any man with half a brain, who can get one eye open.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She's all right.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Behind every ridiculous statement is always hidden the true cause.  What is it? You have a fight?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Her father loading up the shotgun?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: It's happened before, you know! Some of the world's happiest marriage have started 'under the gun' you might say.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She's just not the girl for me.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: She's only perfect.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Too perfect. Too beautiful, too talented, too sophisticated, too everything -- but what I want.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Is what you want something you can discuss?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's very simple. She belongs in that rarefied atmosphere of Park Avenue, expensive restaurants, and literary cocktail parties.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: People with sense can belong wherever they're put.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Can you see her tramping around the world with a camera bum who never has more than a week's salary in the bank?  If only she was ordinary.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You're never going to marry?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Probably. But when I do, it'll be to someone who thinks of life as more than a new dress, a lobster dinner, and the latest scandal. I need a woman who'll go anywhere, do anything, and love it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The only honest thing to do is call it off. Let her look for somebody else.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I can just hear you now. "Get out of here you perfect, wonderful woman! You're too good for me!"

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's the hard part.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Jefferies. I'm not educated. I'm not even sophisticated. But I can tell you this -- when a man and a woman see each other, and like each other -- they should come together -- wham like two taxies on Broadway. Not sit around studying each other like specimens in at bottle.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There's an intelligent way to approach marriage.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Intelligence! Nothing has caused the human race more trouble. Modern marriage!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: We've progressed emotionally in --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Baloney! Once it was see somebody, get excited, get married -- Now, it's read books, fence with four syllable words, psychoanalyze each other until you can't tell a petting party from a civil service exam

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: People have different emotional levels that --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Ask for trouble and you get it. Why there's a good boy in my neighborhood who went with a nice girl across the street for three years. Then he refused to marry her. Why? -- Because she only scored sixty-one on a Look Magazine marriage quiz!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: When I married Myles, we were both maladjusted misfits. We still are. And we've loved every minute of it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's fine, Stella. Now would you make me a sandwich?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Okay -- but I'm going to spread some common sense on the bread. Lisa Fremont's loaded to her fingertips with love for you. I'll give you two words of advice. Marry her.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She pay you much?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Window shopper.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: How's your leg?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Mmmm -- hurts a little.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And your stomach?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Empty as a football.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And you love life?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not too active.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Anything else bothering you?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Lisa --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Carol --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Fremont.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The Lisa Fremont who never wears the same dress twice?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Only because it's expected of her.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Right off the Paris plane. Think it will sell?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Depends on the quote. Let's see -- there's the plane tickets over, import duties, hidden taxes, profit markups --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: -- A steal at eleven hundred dollars.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That dress should be listed on the stock exchange.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: We sell a dozen a day in this price range.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Who buys them? Tax collectors?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Even if I had to pay, it would be worth it -- just for the occasion.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Something big going on somewhere?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Going on right here. It's a big night.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's just a run-of-the-mill Monday. The calendar's loaded with them.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's opening night of the last depressing week of L. B. Jefferies in a cast.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hasn't been any big demand for tickets.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: That's because I bought out the house. This cigarette box has seen better days.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Picked it up in Shanghai -- which has also seen better days.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's cracked -- and you never use it. And it's too ornate. I'm sending up a plain, flat silver one -- with just your initials engraved.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now that's no way to spend your hard- earned money!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I wanted to, Jeff.  Oh!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What would you think of starting off with dinner at the "21"?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You have, perhaps, an ambulance outside?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Thank you for waiting Carl.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Kitchen's on the left. I'll take the wine.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr Jefferies.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Just put everything right in the oven Carl. On "low."

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Let's open the wine now. It's a Montrachet.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: A big glassful.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Big enough?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Fine. Corkscrew's on the right.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I couldn't think of anything more boring and tiresome than what you've been through. And the last week must be the hardest.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah -- I want to get this thing off and get moving.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Well, I'm going to make this a week you'll never forget.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Let me, madam.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: This will take care of the taxi as well.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Thank you, Miss Fremont.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Have a pleasant dinner, Mr. Jefferies.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What a day I've had!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Tired?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Not a bit. I was all morning in a sales meeting. Then over to the Waldorf for a quick drink with Madame Dufresne -- just over from Paris. With some spy reports. Back to the "21" for lunch with the Harper's Bazaar people -- that's when I ordered dinner. Then two Fall showings -- twenty blocks apart. Then I had to have a cocktail with Leland and Slim Hayward -- we're trying to get his next show.  Then I had to dash back and change.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Tell me -- what was Slim Hayward wearing?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: She looked very cool. She had on a mint green --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And to think, I planted three nice items about you in the columns today.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You can't buy that kind of publicity.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's good news.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Someday you might want to open up your own studio here.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How could I run it from say -- Pakistan?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- isn't it time you came home? You could pick your assignment.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I wish there was one I wanted.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Make the one you want.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You mean leave the magazine?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: For yourself -- and me.  I could get you a dozen assignments tomorrow... fashion, portraits --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Don't laugh. -- I could do it!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's what I'm afraid of.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I could see you looking handsome and successful in a dark blue flannel suit.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Let's not talk any more nonsense, huh?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'd better start setting up for dinner.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: That's what is know as "manless melancholia."

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Miss Lonely Hearts. At least that's something you'll never have to worry about.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Oh? You can see my apartment all the way up on 63rd street?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not exactly -- but we have a little apartment here that's probably about as popular as yours.  You, of course, remember Miss Torso.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, she picked the most prosperous looking one.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: She's not in love with him -- or any of them.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How can you tell that -- from here?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You said it resembled my apartment, didn't you?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Where's that music coming from?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Oh... some songwriter. In the studio apartment. Lives alone. Probably had an unhappy marriage.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I think it's enchanting.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Almost as if it were being written especially for us.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No wonder he's having so much trouble with it.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Well, at least you can't say the dinner isn't right.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa, it's perfect  As always.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: There can't be that much difference between people and the way they live! We all eat, talk, drink, laugh, sleep, wear clothes --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well now, look --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: If you're saying all this just because you don't want to tell me the truth, because you're hiding something from me, then maybe I can understand --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There's nothing I'm hiding. It's just that --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It doesn't make sense to me. What's so different about it here from over there, or any place you go, that one person couldn't live in both places just as easily?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Some people can. Now if you'll let me explain --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What is it but traveling from one place to another, taking pictures? It's just like being a tourist on an endless vacation.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: All right. That's your opinion. You're entitled to it, but --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's ridiculous for you to say that it can only be done by a special, private little group of anointed people.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I made a simple, but true statement and I'll back it up, if you'll just shut up for a minute!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: If your opinion is as rude as your manner, I'm not sure I want to hear it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa, simmer down -- will you?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You can't fit in here -- I can't fit in there. According to you, people should be born, live an die on the same --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa! Shut up!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Did you ever eat fish heads and rice?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You might have to, if you went with me. Ever try to keep warm in a C-54, at fifteen thousand feet, at twenty below zero?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Oh, I do that all the time. Whenever I have a few minutes after lunch.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Ever get shot at, run over, sandbagged at night because people got unfavorable publicity from your camera?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Those high heels would be a lot of use in the jungle -- and those nylons and six-ounce lingerie --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Three.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, they'd be very stylish in Finland -- just before you froze to death. Begin to get the idea?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: If there's one thing I know, it's how to wear the proper clothes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Huh? Try and find a raincoat in Brazil. Even when it isn't raining  Lisa, on this job you carry one suitcase. Your home is the available transportation. You sleep rarely, bathe even less, and sometime the food you even look at when they were alive!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff, you don't have to be deliberately repulsive just to impress me I'm wrong.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: If anything, I'm making it sound good.  Let's face it, Lisa... you aren't made for that kind of a life. Few people are.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You're too stubborn to argue with.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm not stubborn! I'm truthful!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I know. A lesser man would have told me it was one long holiday -- and I would have awakened to a rude disillusionment.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now if you want to get vicious, I'd be very happy to accommodate you!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: So that's it. You won't stay here -- I can't go with you.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It would be the wrong thing.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You don't think either one of us could ever change?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Right now, it doesn't seem so.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'm in love with you. I don't care what you do for a living. Somehow I would just like to be part of it.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And it's deflating to find out that the only way I can be part of it -- is to take out a subscription to your magazine. I guess I'm not the girl I thought I was.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There's nothing wrong with you, Lisa. You have the town in the palm of your hand.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Goodbye, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You mean "goodnight."

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I mean what I said.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Can't we just sort of keep things status quo?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Without any future?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well -- when'll I see you again?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Not for a long time. Not, at least until --  -- tomorrow night.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Gunnison?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Yeah. Is that you, Jeff?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's me.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Something wrong?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The word is "everything." Now what time does my plane leave Tuesday?

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Jeff --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I don't care where it goes -- just as long as I'm on it.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Okay. Indo-China. Tuesday. We'll pick you up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's more like it. Goodnight, old buddy.

Speaker: gunnison
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You'd think the rain would have cooled things off. All it did was make the heat wet.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's a stiff one.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: The insurance Company would be a lot happier if you slept in your bed, not the wheelchair.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How did you know!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Eyes bloodshot. Must have been staring out the window for hours.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I was.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What'll you do if one of them catches you?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Depends one which one.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now Miss Torso, for example --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Keep your mind off her.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She's real eat, drink and be merry girl.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: And she'll end up fat, alcoholic and miserable.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Speaking of misery, Miss Lonely Hearts drank herself to sleep again. Alone.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Poor girl. Someday she'll find her happiness.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: And some man will lose his.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Isn't there anyone in the neighborhood who might cast an eye in her direction?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, the salesman could be available soon.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: He and his wife splitting up?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's hard to figure. He went out several time last night, in the rain carrying his sample case.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Isn't he a salesman?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now what could he sell at three in the morning?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Flashlights. Luminous dials for watches. House numbers that light up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He was taking something out of the apartment. I'm certain.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: His personal effects. He's probably running away -- the coward.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Sometimes it's worse to stay than it is to run.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: But it takes a particularly low type of man to do it.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What about this morning? Any developments?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No. The shades are still drawn in their apartment.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: They're up now.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Get back! Out of sight! Quick!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What is it? What's the matter?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The salesman's looking out his window.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: A Federal offense.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Get back there! He'll see you!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I'm not shy. I've been looked at before.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's not an ordinary look. It's the kind of look a man gives when he's afraid somebody might be watching him.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Goodbye, Mr. Jefferies. I'll see you tomorrow.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: And don't sleep in the chair again.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Great conversationalist.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Will you take those binoculars out of the case and bring them to me.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Trouble. I cam smell it. I'll be glad when they crack that cast, and I get out of here.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: How far does a girl have to go -- before you notice her?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: If she's pretty enough, she doesn't have to go anywhere. She just has to "be".

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Well, "ain't I?" -- Pay attention to me.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm not exactly on the other side of the room.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Your mind is. And when I want a man, I want all of him.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Don't you ever have any problems?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I have one now.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: So do I.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Tell me about it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Why would a man leave his apartment three times, on a rainy night, with a suitcase? And come back three times?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: He likes the way his wife welcomes him home.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not that salesman's wife. And why didn't he go to work today?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Homework. It's more interesting.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What's interesting about a butcher's knife and a small saw wrapped up in a newspaper?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Nothing, thank heaven.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Why hasn't he gone into his wife's bedroom all day?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I wouldn't dare answer that.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa -- there's something terribly wrong.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And I'm afraid it's with me.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Something too frightful to utter.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He went out a few minutes ago -- in his undershirt -- and he hasn't come back yet.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You know -- that would be terrible job to tackle.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How would you begin to cut up a human body?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- I'll be honest with you -- you're beginning to scare me a little.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- did you hear what I said? You're beginning to --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He's coming back!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- if you could only see yourself.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now, Lisa --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: -- with, with binoculars, and with wild opinions about every little movement you see -- is, is diseased!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Do you think I consider this recreation?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I don't know what you consider it -- but if you don't stop it, I'm getting out of here.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You'd better before you catch the disease!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What is it you're looking for?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I want to find out what's wrong with the salesman's wife. Does that make me sound like a madman?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What makes you think something's wrong with her?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: A lot of things. She's an invalid who needs constant care -- and yet the husband nor anyone else has been in there all day.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Maybe she died.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Where's the doctor -- the undertakers?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: She could be under sedatives, sleeping.  He's in the room now.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa, please!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: There's nothing to see.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There is -- I've seen things through that window! Bickering, family fights, mysterious trips at night, knives, saws, rope -- and since last evening, not a sight or sound of his wife! Now you tell me where she is and what she's doing!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Maybe he's leaving his wife. I don't know, and I don't care. Lots of people have saws, knives and ropes around their houses. Lots of men don't speak to their wives all day. Lots of wives nag, and men hate them, and trouble starts -- but very, very, very few of them end up in murder -- if that's what you're thinking.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's pretty hard to stay away from that word isn't is?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You could see all the things he did, couldn't you?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What are you getting at?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You could see that he did because he had the shades in his apartment up, and walked along the corridor, and the streets and the backyard?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff, do you think a murderer would let you see all that? That he shouldn't keep his shades down and hide behind them?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's where he's being clever. Acting nonchalant.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: And that's where you're not being clever. He wouldn't parade his crime in front of the open shades.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: For all you know -- there's something a lot more sinister going on behind those shades.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No comment.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Don't you see how silly you're being?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Okay, Lisa -- probably you're right. He's probably in the bedroom now, entertaining his wife with the indian rope trick. I'll admit to criminal insanity. Now when do I start the cure?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Let's start from the beginning again, Jeff. Tell me everything you saw -- and what you think it means.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The name on the second floor rear mailbox reads Mr. And Mrs. Lars, that's L-A-R-S, Lars Thorwald.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What's the apartment house number?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: 125 West Ninth Street.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thanks, Lisa.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Okay, chief. What's my next assignment.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: To get on home.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: All right -- but what's he doing now?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Just sitting in the living room. In the dark. And he hasn't gone near the bedroom. Now get some sleep. Goodnight.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Look, Doyle -- it's just one of those things I can't tell you on the phone. You have to be here, and see the whole set-up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: It's probably nothing important -- just a little neighborhood murder, that's all. As a matter of fact, I did say "murder".

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: My only thought was to throw a little business your way. A good detective, I reasoned, would jump at the chance to detect.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, I usually took my best pictures on my day off.  Okay, Doyle -- soon as you can.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella, I -- I can't tell you what a welcome sight this is. No wonder your husband's still in love with you.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Police?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You called the police?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Oh. Well, yes and no. It wasn't an official call. He's just a friend.  An old, ornery friend.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Now just where do you suppose he cut her up?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Oh -- of course! In the bathtub. That's the only place he could wash away the blood.

Speaker: stella's voice
Dialogue: He'd better get that trunk out of there before is starts to leak.

Speaker: girl's voice
Dialogue: H-a-a-r-r-e-e...

Speaker: stella's voice
Dialogue: Look! Look -- Mr. Jefferies!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now we're going to lose it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella, don't do anything reckless!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I'm just going to get the name of their truck!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll watch the alleyway -- in case it goes that way.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Long Distance.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You didn't see the killing, or the body? How do you know there was a murder?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Because everything that man's done has been suspicious. Trips at night in the rain, saws, knives, trunks with rope, and a wife that isn't there any more.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I'll admit it all has a mysterious sound -- but is could mean a number of different things. Murder is the least likely.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Go ahead, Doyle -- tell me he's an unemployed magician -- amusing the neighborhood with sleight-of-hand.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It's too stupid and obvious a way to murder -- in full view of fifty windows -- and then sit over there --  -- smoking a cigar -- waiting for the police to pick him up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, officer -- do your duty.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You've got a lot to lean about homicide, Jeff. Morons have committed murder so shrewdly that it took a hundred trained police minds to catch them. That salesman wouldn't just knock off his wife after dinner, toss her in a trunk and put her in storage.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll bet it's been done.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Almost everything's been done -- under panic. But this is a thousand to one shot. That man's still sitting around his apartment; he isn't panicked.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You think I made all this up?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I think you saw something -- that probably has a very simple explanation.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: For instance?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: His wife took a trip.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: She -- was -- an -- invalid!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You told me.  I've got to run, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: All right -- you don't believe me.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I -- uh -- won't report it to the Department. Let me poke into a little on my own. No point in you getting any ridiculous publicity.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We know the wife is gone. I'll see if I can find out where.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Do that.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You have any headaches lately?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not 'til you showed up.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Well, it'll wear off in time -- along with the hallucinations. See you around.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: By the way  what happened to your leg?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I was jaywalking.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The Indianapolis Speedway.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: During the race?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yup. It sure stopped traffic.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: He has a six months lease, and has used up a little over five and a half months of it.  Quiet. Drinks, but not to drunkenness. Pays his bill promptly, with money earned as a consume jewelry salesman -- wholesale. Keeps to himself, and none of the neighbors got close to him, or his wife.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I think they missed their chance with her.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: She never left the apartment --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Then where is she -- in the ice box?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: -- until yesterday morning.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What time?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Six ayem.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I think that's about the time I fell asleep.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Too bad. The Thorwalds were just leaving the apartment house at that time.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Feel a little foolish?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: How's your wife?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Oh -- oh, she's fine.  Just fine.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Who said they left then?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Who left -- where?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The Thorwalds -- at six in the morning?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The building superintendent, and two tenants. Flat statements -- no hesitation. And they all jibed to the letter. The Thorwalds were leaving for the railroad station.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now how could anybody guess that? They had, perhaps, signs on their luggage, "Grand Central Or Bust!"?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The superintendent met Thorwald coming back. He said Thorwald told him he had just put his wife on the train for the country.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: A very convenient guy -- this superintendent. Have you checked his bank deposits lately?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Jeff -- huh?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well -- what good is his information?!! It's a second-hand version of an unsupported statement by the murderer himself -- Thorwald! Anybody actually see the wife get on the train?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I hate to remind you -- but this all started because you said she was murdered. Now did anyone, including you, actually see her murdered?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Doyle -- are you interested in solving a case, or making me look foolish?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: If possible -- both.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well then do a good job of it! Get over there, and search Thorwald's apartment! It must be knee-deep in evidence.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I can't do that.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I mean when he goes out for a paper, or a drink, or something. What he doesn't know won't hurt him.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I can't do it even if he's gone.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What's the matter? Does he have a courtesy card from the police department?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Now don't get me mad! Even a detective can't walk in anybody's apartment and search it. If I were ever caught in there, I'd lose my badge inside of ten minutes!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Just make sure you're not caught. If you find something, you've got a murderer and nobody will care about a couple of house rules. If you find nothing -- he's clear.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: At the risk of sounding stuffy, Jeff -- I'll remind you of the Constitution, and the phrase "search warrant" issued by a judge who knows the Bill of Rights verbatim. He must ask for evidence.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Give him evidence.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I can hear myself starting out. "Your Honor -- I have a friend who's an amateur sleuth, an one night, after a heavy supper --"  He'd throw the New York State Penal Code right in my face. -- And it's six volumes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: By morning there might not be anything left to find in his apartment.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: A detective's nightmare.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What do you need before you can search -- bloody footsteps leading up to the door?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: One thing I don't need is heckling! You called and asked me for help -- and now you're acting like a taxpayer!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: How did we ever stand each other in that same plane for three years?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You know, every day for three years I asked myself that same question?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Ever get an answer?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah -- frequently -- it ran something like this: "Your request for transfer turned down --"

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Sorry I had to turn it down.  I'm going over to the railroad station and check Thorwald's story.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Forget the story -- find the trunk. Mrs. Thorwald's in it!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Oh -- I almost forgot!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The message read "Arrived O.K. Already feeling better. Love, Anna."

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Is -- is Anna -- who I think it is?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Mrs. Thorwald.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Anything you need?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yeah. A good detective.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Mrs. Doyle?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Jeff again.  Has Tom come in yet?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You haven't even heard from him?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm afraid it is, Tess.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Tell him not to waste time calling. To get over here soon as he can. I think Thorwald's pulling out tonight.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He knows.  Don't worry, Tess. It's a man.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mrs Doyle.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Long distance again.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Quick. Take a look. Thorwald's getting ready to pull out for good!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It doesn't seem to be in any hurry.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He was just laying all his things out on one of the beds! Coats, suits, shirts, sox, even his wife's --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That alligator bag his wife had on the bedpost --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He had it hidden in the dresser! Well, at least it was in there. He took it out, went to the phone and called somebody long distance. -- His wife's jewelry was in the handbag. And something about it worried him. He was asking somebody advice over the phone.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Someone not his wife?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I never saw him ask her for advise before.  But she volunteered plenty.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I wonder where he's going now?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Suppose he doesn't come back again?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He will. All his things are still piled on the bed.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Well, I guess it's safe to put on some lights now.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not yet!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He must have gone somewhere to the right.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: All day long I've tried to keep my mind on work.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thinking about Thorwald?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Did you hear from him again -- since he left?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not a word. He was going to check on the railroad station, and the trunk. He must be still on it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Something on your mind, Lisa?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It doesn't make sense to me.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What doesn't?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Women aren't that unpredictable.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa -- I can't guess what you're thinking.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: A woman has a favorite handbag -- it always hangs on her bedpost where she can get at it. Then she takes a trip and leaves it behind. Why?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Because she didn't know she was going on a trip -- and where she was going she wouldn't need a handbag.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: But only her husband would know that.  And the jewelry! Women don't keep all their jewelry in a purse, all tangled, getting scratched and twisted up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Do they hide it in their husband's clothes?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: They do not! And they don't leave it behind them. A woman going anywhere but the hospital would always take makeup, perfume and jewelry.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Inside stuff?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Basic equipment. You don't leave it behind in your husband's drawer in your favorite handbag.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm with you, sweetie, but Detective Thomas J. Doyle has a pat answer for that.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: That Mrs. Thorwald left at six ayem yesterday with her husband?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's what the witnesses told him.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Well, I have a pat rebuttal for Mr. Doyle -- that couldn't be Mrs. Thorwald -- or I don't know women.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Still -- those witnesses.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: We'll agree they saw a woman -- but she wasn't Mrs. Thorwald. -- That is, yet.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Come here.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'd like to see your friend's face when we tell him. He doesn't sound like much of a detective.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Don't be too hard on him. He's a steady worker. I wish he'd get there, though.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Don't rush me. We have all night.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: We have all -- what?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Night. I'm going to stay with you.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You'll have to clear that through my landlord --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I have the whole weekend off.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well that's fine, but I only have one bed, and --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Say anything else, and I'll stay tomorrow night too.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa, I won't be able to give you any --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: -- pajamas.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You said I'd have to live out of one suitcase  I'll bet yours isn't this small?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's a suitcase?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: A Mark Cross overnight case, anyway. Compact, but ample enough.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'll trade you -- my feminine intuition for a bed for the night.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'd be no better than Thorwald, to refuse.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: There's that song again.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Where does a man get the inspiration for a song like that?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: From his landlord -- once a month.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's utterly beautiful.  I wish I could be creative.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You are. You have a talent for creating difficult situations.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I do?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Staying the night here, uninvited.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Surprise -- is the most important element of attack.  And beside, you're not up on your private eye literature. When they're in trouble, it's always their Girl Friday who gets them out of it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: The same girl who keeps him out of the clutches of seductive show girls, and over-passionate daughters of the rich.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The same.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: But he never ends up marrying her. Strange.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Why don't I slip into something comfortable?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You mean -- like the kitchen? And make us some coffee?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Exactly what I had in mind -- along with some brandy.

Speaker: girl's voice
Dialogue: H-a-a-r-r-e-e-!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What else do you have on this man Thorwald?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Enough to scare me that you wouldn't get here in time, and we'd lose him.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You think he's getting out of here?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Everything he owns is laid out on the bedroom, ready for packing.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'm just warming some brandy.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Mr. Doyle? -- I presume.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Tom, this is Miss Lisa Fremont.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: We think Thorwald's guilty.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Careful, Tom.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hallo?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Just a minute, please.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Doyle speaking.  Uh-huh. -- Yeah. Mummmm -- Mmm. Hmm -- Okay. Thank you, and goodbye.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: The coffee will be ready soon.  Jeff, aren't you going to tell him about the jewelry?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Jewelry?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He has his wife's jewelry hidden in among his clothes over there.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You sure it belongs to his wife?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It was in her favorite handbag -- And, Mr. Doyle, that can lead to only one conclusion.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Namely?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That wasn't Mrs. Thorwald who left with him yesterday morning?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You figured that out, huh?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's just that women don't leave jewelry behind when they go on a trip.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Come on, Tom -- you don't really need any of this information, do you?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, I don't.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Lars Thorwald is no more a murderer than I am.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You mean you can explain everything that went on over there -- and is still going on?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: And neither can you.  That's a secret and private world you're looking into out there. People do a lot at things in private that they couldn't explain in public.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Like disposing of their wives?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Get that idea out of your mind. It will only lead you in the wrong direction.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: But Tom -- the saw, the knives --

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Did you ever own a saw?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, in the garage, back home, we --

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: And how many people did you cut up with the couple of with it? Or hundred knives you've probably owned in your lifetime?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: But I'm not a killer!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Your logic is backward.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You can't ignore the wife disappearing! And the trunk -- and the jewelry -- !

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I checked the railroad station. He bought a ticket. He put her on the train ten minutes later. Destination: Merritsville. Witnesses. This deep.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It might have been a woman -- but it couldn't have been Mrs. Thorwald. That jewelry --

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Look, Miss Fremont. That feminine intuition sells magazines -- but in real life, it's still a fairy tale. I don't know how many wasted years I've spent running down leads based on women's intuitions.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I take it you didn't find the trunk -- And this is just an old speech you once gave at the Policeman's Ball.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I found the trunk -- a half hour after I left here.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Of course, it's normal for a man to tie his trunk up with a heavy rope.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: When the lock is broken -- yes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What was in the trunk? A surly note to me?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Mrs. -- Thorwald's -- clothes. -- Clean -- carefully packed -- not too stylish -- but presentable.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Didn't you take it to the crime lab?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I sent it on its merry and legal way.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Why -- when a woman only goes on a simple trip, does she take everything she owns?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Let the female psychology department handle that one.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I would say that is looked as if she wasn't coming back.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: That's what they call a family problem.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: If his wife wasn't coming back -- why didn't he tell his landlord? -- I'll answer it for you -- because he had something to hide.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Do -- uh -- you tell your landlord everything?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I told you to be careful.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: If I'd been careful piloting that reconnaissance plane, you wouldn't have taken the kind of pictures that got you a medal, a big job, fame, money --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: All the things I hate.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Now -- what do you say we sit down to a quiet, friendly drink or two -- forget all about this, and tell lies about the old days in the war? Hmmm? He looks from one to the other.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You're through with the case?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: There isn't any "case" to be through with, Miss Fremont. Now let's get down to that friendly drink.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Maybe you're right. I guess I'd better get home and get some sleep.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I'm not much of a snifter.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: If you need any more help, Jeff -- consult the yellow pages of your telephone directory.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I hate funny exit lines.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Who was the trunk addressed to?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Mrs. Anna Thorwald.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Let's wait and see who picks it up.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Oh -- that phone call!  I gave them your number -- hope you don't mind.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That depends on who "they" were.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The police Department at Merritsville. They called to report. The trunk was just picked up -- by Mrs. Anna Thorwald.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Don't stay up too late.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Look.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: As much as I hate to give Thomas J. Doyle too much credit, he might have gotten a hold of something when he said this was pretty private stuff going on out there.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Do you suppose it's ethical to watch a man with binoculars, and a long- focus lens -- until you can see the freckles on the back of his neck, and almost read his mail -- do you suppose it's ethical even if you prove he didn't commit a crime?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'm not much on rear window ethics.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Of course, they have the same chance. They can look at me like a bug under glass, if they want to.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- if anybody walked in here, I don't think they'd believe what they see.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You and me with long faces -- plunged into despair -- because we find out that a man didn't kill his wife. We're two of the most frightening ghouls I've ever known.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: You'd think we could be a little bit happy that the poor woman is alive and well.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Whatever happened to that old saying "Love Thy Neighbor."

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I think I'll start reviving it tomorrow, with say -- Miss Torso for a start?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Show's over for tonight.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Preview -- of the coming attractions.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Did Mr. Doyle think I stole this case.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No, Lisa -- I don't think he did.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'll rephrase the question.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Do you like it?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: -- I might give up bachelorhood.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: lonely hearts
Dialogue: It's dead! It's been strangled and the neck is broken!

Speaker: siffleuse
Dialogue: Which one of you did it?  Even see. But I couldn't imagine any Even of you being so low that you'd kill a little helpless, friendly dog! The only thing in this whole neighborhood who liked anybody!

Speaker: siffleuse
Dialogue: Did you kill him because he liked you? Just because he liked you?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: For a minute, Doyle almost had me convinced I was wrong.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: But you're not?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: In the whole courtyard, only one person didn't come to the window.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Why would Thorwald want to kill a dog?  Because it knew too much?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Do you think this was worth waiting all day to see?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Is he cleaning house?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He's washing down the bathroom walls.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Must have splattered a lot.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Well, why not? That's what we're all thinking. He killed her in there, and he has to wipe up the stains before he leaves.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Stella, your choice of words --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Nobody's invented polite words yet for killing.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa -- Lisa -- on the shelf over there -- get me the small yellow box --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: And that little viewer.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I think this is the one.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- what are you looking for?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Something -- that if I'm right -- might solve a murder.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Mrs. Thorwald?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Uh-uh. The dog. I think I know now why Thorwald killed it.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You take a look and tell me what you see.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now take it away.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It's just a picture of the backyard, that's all.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I know. But there's one important change. The flowers in Thorwald's pet flower bed.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You mean the one the dog was sniffing around?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Look at that flower bed.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There's a dip at this end. And since when do flowers grow shorter in two weeks?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: There's something buried there.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Mrs. Thorwald!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You haven't spent much time in cemeteries, have you?  Mr. Thorwald could hardly put his wife into a plot of ground scarcely one foot square.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Unless, he puts in standing on end -- which would be very original and not require the use of either a knife or a saw. My guess is she's scattered all over town. A leg in the East River -- an arm --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Stella, please.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Something's in there. Those flowers have been taken up, and put back again.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: It could be -- the knife, and the saw.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Call Lieutenant Doyle!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: No -- let's wait. Let's wait until it gets dark. I'll go over and dig it up!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: And you're not going to dig up anything, an get your neck broken too.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What we've got to do is find some way to get in there, and --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: He's starting to pack.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What are you going back for?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You did it, Thorwald! You did it!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa! Look out! He's coming!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You shouldn't have let her do that! If he ever --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Look!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Thank heaven that's over!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I have a feeling we've just begun.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No doubt of it. He's leaving. The question is -- when?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Mind if I use the portable keyhole?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Not as long as you tell me what you're looking at.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I wonder.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Miss Lonely Hearts just laid out something that looks like sodium trieckonal capsules.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You can tell that from here?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I handled enough of those red pills to put everybody in New Jersey asleep for the winter.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Would four of them -- ?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: No -- but it makes the rest easy to take. And she's reading the Bible.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Then I wouldn't worry too much. But let's keep an eye on her.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You know? You might not be too bad a bargain for Lisa after all.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: You don't say! I might just take that compliment as an insult.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Wasn't that close?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Too close.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What was his reaction? I mean when he looked at the note?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Well, it wasn't the kind of expression that would get him a quick loan at the bank.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- how did I do?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Real professional. Would have made a great layout for the Bazaar. The model pressed back against a brick wall, eyes wild, tense. Low cut bodice, in new suspicious black, with a --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You'd make a good door prize at a wake.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- the handbag.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Suppose Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring was among the jewelry he has in the handbag.  During that phone conversation he held up three rings -- one with a diamond -- one with a big stone of some kind -- and one plain gold band.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Do you ever leave yours at home?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: The only way anybody could get that off would be to chop my finger -- Let's go down and find out what's buried in the garden.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Why not? I always wanted to meet Mrs. Thorwald.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What are you two talking about?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Got a shovel?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: There's probably one in the basement.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now wait a minute --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff, if you're squeamish, just don't look.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now hold on. I'm not a bit squeamish about what might be under those flowers -- but I don't care to watch two women end up like that dog --

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You know, Miss Fremont -- he might just have something there.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: There's no point in taking unnecessary chances.  Give me the phone book, Lisa.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Maybe I can get Thorwald out of the apartment.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: We only need a few minutes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll try to give you at least fifteen minutes.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm using that word "we" a little too freely, I guess. I don't take any of the chances.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Shall we vote him in, Stella?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Unanimously.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Go ahead, Thorwald -- pick it up. You're curious. You wonder if it's your girl friend calling. The one you killed for. Pick it up, Thorwald!

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Did you get my note?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well -- did you get it, Thorwald?

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll give you a chance to find out. Meet me in the bar at the Brevoort -- and do it right away.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Why should I?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: For a little business meeting -- to settle the estate of your late wife.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: I don't know what you mean.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Now stop wasting time, Thorwald, or I'll hang up and call the police.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: I only have a hundred dollars or so.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That's a start. I'm at the Brevoort now. I'll be looking for you.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Let's go, Stella.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: One of you watch this window. If I see him coming back, I'll signal with a flashbulb.

Speaker: baby sitter
Dialogue: This is Doyle's house.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: This is L. B. Jefferies, a friend of Tom's. Who am I talking with?

Speaker: baby sitter
Dialogue: This is the baby sitter.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Oh. When are they expected home?

Speaker: baby sitter
Dialogue: I'm hired 'til one. They went to dinner and maybe night-clubbing.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Well, if he calls in, tell him to get in touch with L. B. Jefferies right away. I might have quite a surprise for him.

Speaker: baby sitter
Dialogue: Does he have your number, Mr. Jefferies?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: He has it. Thank you.

Speaker: baby sitter
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa -- no!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Come on. Come on! Get out of there!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Ring Thorwald's phone the second you see him on the way back!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'm going to ring him now!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Give her another minute -- She's doing this for you.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Miss Lonely Hearts!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Call the police!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Maybe that music will delay her taking the pills.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa! Lisa!

Speaker: police
Dialogue: Precinct Six -- Sergeant Allgood.

Speaker: police
Dialogue: Precinct Six -- Sergeant Allgood.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: A man is assaulting a woman at one two five west ninth street. Second floor rear. Make it fast.

Speaker: police
Dialogue: Your name?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: L. B. Jefferies.

Speaker: police
Dialogue: Phone number?

Speaker: police
Dialogue: Two minutes.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella -- what can we do?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: There they are.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What's she trying to do? Why doesn't she turn him in?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Smart girl.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Smart? She'll be arrested!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That'll get her out of there, won't it?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Mrs. Thorwald's ring!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella! The lights! He'd seen us!

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: When you took your first snapshot -- did you ever think it would bring you to this?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Stella -- how long do you think he'll stay there?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Unless he's dumber than I think, he won't wait 'til his lease is up.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: My billfold! In the right hand drawer.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: What do you need money for?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: To bail Lisa out of jail.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: You know -- you could just leave her there until after next Tuesday -- so you could sneak away safely -- as planned.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: One hundred and twenty-seven.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: How much do you think you'll need?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: First offense burglary --  The piggy bank.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Ten here.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Thirty-three here. Totals one-ninety. Not enough.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: I got twenty or so in my purse. Give me what you've got.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: What about the rest?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: When those cops get a look at Miss Fremont -- they'll even contribute.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I'll tell you who it is when you get back.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Jefferies.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: This is Doyle, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Tom, I've got something real big for you.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Look Jeff, don't louse up my night with another man killer stuffing a grisly trunk that turns out to be --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Listen to me! Lisa's been arrested.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Your Lisa?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: My Lisa. She went into Thorwald's apartment, and he came back. The only way I could get her out was to call the police.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I told you that --

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I know what you told me! She went in to get evidence, and she came out with it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Like Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring. If that woman were still alive, she'd be wearing it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: A possibility.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: A fact! Last night he killed a dog for pawing in his garden. Why? Because he had something buried in there. Something a dog could scent.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Like an old hambone?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I don't know what pet name Thorwald had for his wife. And that night he went out half a dozen times with the metal suitcase. He wasn't taking his possessions, because they're up in his apartment now!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You think perhaps it was "old hambone?"

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: In sections! And one other thing, doubting Tom -- it just occurred to me that all the calls Thorwald made were long distance! If he called his wife the day she left -- after she arrived in Merritsville -- why did she need to send him a postcard saying she'd arrived?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Where'd they take Lisa?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Precinct Six. I sent a friend over with bail money.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Maybe you won't need it. I'll run it down, Jeff.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Just don't dally. Thorwald knows he's being watched. He won't hang around long.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: If that ring checks out, we'll give him an escort. So long.

Speaker: miss torso
Dialogue: Have you heard that song he's been writing?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: What do you want from me?

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Your friend -- the girl -- could have turned me in. Why didn't she?

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: What is it you want? A lot of money? I don't have any money.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Say something!

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Say something! Tell me what you want!

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Can you get me that ring back?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Tell her to bring it back!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: I can't. The police have it by now.

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: Then if the police get me -- you won't be around to laugh!

Speaker: thorwald
Dialogue: I'll give you a good look out the window.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff! Jeff!

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Creel! Your Thirty-eight!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Jeff -- Jeff darling!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Don't move. Try to lie still.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Lisa -- I -- I -- can't tell you how scared I was that you -- you might --

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Shut up. I'm all right.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Think you've got enough for a search warrant now?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Oh sure. Sure. I can make it.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Lieutenant Doyle?

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Thorwald's ready to take us on a tour of the East River.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Did he say what was buried in the flower bed?

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Yeah. It's over in his apartment. In a hat box. Wanna look?

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Oh, no thanks -- I don't want any of part of her  What did I say?
